title: Reverse engineering TPMS sensor data [closed]
content:
Closed. This question needs details or clarity. It is not currently accepting answers. Want to improve this question? Add details and clarify the problem by editing this post. Closed 9 years ago. Improve this question I'm trying to reverse engineer data received from TPMS (car tyre pressure) sensors. I used 
rtl_433
tool to capture the data from sensor at 433 MHz. Tool was able to detect data is using FSK modulation and Manchester encoding. Using 
reveng
I confirmed that end of data consists of 8 bit CRC. At the beginning is 32-bit sensor id, then there should be tyre pressure, temperature data and at least few status bits (together 5 bytes of unknown data). I'm not sure if these data are 8/10/16 bits each, nor their endianess or int/float. I have made a simple PHP script to try several combinations, but didn't get meaningful values with any of them. The sensor IDs are: 
1c/1d/1e/1f e0 ed a5
. Output from 
reveng -a 4 -w 8 -s
: 
width=8  poly=0x07  init=0xd3  refin=false  refout=false  xorout=0x00  check=0xd4  name=(none)
Tyre pressures as shown on car display were from 211 kPa in the beginning to 220 kPa at the end after few minutes of driving. Outside temperature was about 5 degC, so final tyre temp could be maybe 15-20 degC at the end, so the question is how to decode the data get these values? Here is data from 4 sensors:

comments.text: For completeness: this question was asked again with more details and some comments: reverseengineering.stackexchange.com/q/11539/2781
